@b-slim there are three "real" bugs fixed in this PR, other changes are dead code removals mostly:
 1) https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/6490/files#diff-03e48730fe9116ce0c8c99610d4e37f0L183: could lead to NPE in runtime, ternary operator + primitives + null = bad!
 2) https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/6490/files#diff-03e48730fe9116ce0c8c99610d4e37f0L221, same as the previous one
 3) https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/6490/files#diff-e212e5107b0e6b3bb4112d2d097c78a1R815: a property is not copied in a copy constructor

I didn't add new tests, such bugs should be now catched, well, by the newly added inspections and error-prone rules.

Hi @a2l007, would you elaborate more on the default behavior? Is this issue to add an assumption that all custom type metrics should be able to be converted to double?

first request => you get paging identifiers in response.
Use the first response paging identifiers for second request => you get new paging identifiers in second response.
Now merge the first response paging identifiers with the second response paging identifiers for the third request.
Essentially, you are overwriting the entries in first with the entries in 2 for the merged paging identifiers.

SUGGESTION: Hope druid does that internally in the next versions!

so the idea is that "joint tables" (that is tables to be joined together) will be sharded by same "join key" and special arrangements are made so that all shards for same join key for the "joint tables" goto same historical nodes and join can be done locally on historicals ?

Is this about creating indexes for numerical columns for faster filtering?

I couldn't really understand the design/plan from the description given. It would be nice if you could elaborate some more or maybe your PR would have that.
Possibly because query/cpu/time is cumulative of multiple cores and multiple segments for same query do get processed in parallel on multiple cores.

@jihoonson The basic requirement is that for custom types, the compare method should not to throw an exception and handle it in a default way. The reasoning behind using the Double comparison as default is that most of the existing type classes(Integer,Long etc) provide a doubleValue() method and therefore I feel it would be reasonable to assume that custom metric types also should be able to override this method. Does it make sense?

> The basic requirement is that for custom types, the compare method should not to throw an exception and handle it in a default way. 

Hmm, I think this would be best if the default behavior can handle most of types. But, in this case, I'm not sure there's a reasonable default behavior. So, I still think it makes more sense to throw an exception if the metric column is an unknown type. With #6505, it will throw the ClassCastException anyway if it can't be casted to Number. 

I wonder if you can explicitly cast the column in the having clause to double in your query. Does it make sense?

I think another way to handle this would be to have an explicit instanceof check for the Number type and in this case, do `Double.compare(d, value.doubleValue());` If it does not fall under this check as well, we could throw the exception. Would this be reasonable?

Nice @weijietong! Would you please add some more details about your implementation which describes 1) how to specify joint tables, 2) how to locate the joint segments in the same historicals, and 3) how join algorithm works? It would be much helpful for reviewers.

I also have some questions about the goal of this issue.
-  Does this support join of realtime dataSources?
- One of the most common use cases is aggregation after join. `SELECT col, count(*) FROM t1, t2 WHERE t1.key = t2.key GROUP BY col` is an example sql. Does this support this kind of query?
- Does this support join of multiple dataSources?

Hmm, that may involve some accuracy loss which can cause inexact result. For example, if `metricValueObj` is a `BigDecimal` containing some value which can't be represented with double, `metricValueObj.doubleValue()` returns a different value. Would you tell me more about your use case? What custom metric type are you using?

@jihoonson I see your point. Regarding the usecase, the custom metric in question is a compressed implementation of `BigDecimal`. In this case, I could use `BigDecimal.compareTo` instead of the Double conversion. Wouldn't this take care of the precision problem?
Thanks. That makes sense to me.

We are not sure what the reason behind this is. Could be a networkproblem with our Rancher installation as well. Or the jets3t Library is not fully compatible with AWS/S3 anymore (Jets3t-0.9.4 is from August 2015 and since then never updated)

But its strange that it started a few days ago till now. Overall the Druid-Cluster is working but the Historical logs got flooded with this error messages

I think this is the expected behavior of the current implementation. What is the improvement you think?

Add a timeout property to control it just like the `handoffConditionTimeout`.  If the tasks get stuck all the time, it would occupy much resources and some new tasks would never get running. I have fixed this in my production cluster by doing so.

Thanks. Do you know where the task is stuck in the codes? 

I think it also makes sense to do retrying with your timeout.
Hmm, maybe timeout isn't necessary for hdfs.

In ForkingTaskRunner call `taskLogPusher.pushTaskLog(task.getId(), logFile)`, then stuck  here : https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/b2d9b6f23dfb828c834a1956f0099b07aa1e400d/extensions-core/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/druid/storage/hdfs/tasklog/HdfsTaskLogs.java#L64

> Hmm, maybe timeout isn't necessary for hdfs.

Any other ideas?

Ah sorry, my bad. Timeout is necessary, but retrying might not.

> In ForkingTaskRunner call taskLogPusher.pushTaskLog(task.getId(), logFile), then stuck here :

I mean, what code in `pushTaskLog`? I guess it's `ByteStreams.copy(in, out)`, but do you know why it happens? In `ByteStreams.copy(in, out)`, there's an infinite loop but it's expected to return if there's any exception. Is `FSDataOutputStream.write()` blocking on errors without throwing exceptions?

> Is FSDataOutputStream.write() blocking on errors without throwing exceptions

Might be, but I'm not very sure and it's not convenient to reproduce. The hadoop cluster maintained by other team in my company, they adopt exponential back-off algorithm to retry when there are errors.
Anyway, I think add timeout logic would be good to avoid things that prevent tasks to finish. I'll open a PR to do this if you think so.

Hmm, I think timeout should be added to inside of `HdfsTaskLogs` if needed because other taskLogPusher implementations can have their own error handling mechanism which can cause blocking for a while. For example, `S3TaskLogs` retries on errors to avoid transient S3 errors. Timeout in `ForkingTaskRunner` can interrupt it before exhausting all retries.

But before that, I think we need to check that other HDFS distributions have the similar issue. If it's common in various distributions, it's worth to handle it. Do you have any idea about this?

@will-lauer ^

LGTM, but I think use such relative path is not a good way since it depends on where you run this file i.e. `run bin/init` would work but `run ./init` would not. Use `dirname $0` to get parent directory of this bash file and tweak the path.
LGTM. @QiuMM's suggestion also sounds good to me though.

Instead of `LookupExtractor@apply()` returning a `String` (which it does now) or a `Map<String, Object>`, I think the correct contract is for a new method that returns a `List<String>` with a default implementation that simply invokes `return Collections.singletonList(apply())`, creating a list from the standard single value return, thus allowing any existing lookups to continue to work without any changes. 

One of the tricky issues here is that `LookupExtractor.unapply()` makes less sense for mutlivalued values. We would need to understand what that API would do for this case.

@weijietong thanks for the answer! I think it's good enough for starting support for join queries. I think there's no rush for making PR(s). 

I wonder https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/4040 is the proposal of this issue. Whether it is or not, I strongly recommend to write a new proposal (or improve the existing one) for your idea, so that others can review its design first. (I guess the design and implementation might have been changed or new stuffs have been added since https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/4040 was written.) This is because this kind of work should be tagged with `Design Review` and get +1s from 3 different committers. The design review would also involve the review on the design of your implementation. According to the review comments, you may need to change some design decisions. This is always easier to do before fully writing your codes. So, it would be better as the proposal shows details. Please check other proposals like https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6319 or https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/4349.
